0.paragraph: Please describe the address of the excavation site in one paragraph.
source:
page_content='1.3 

Project Archaeologist 

The Project Archaeologist for this investigation is Barry Green.  

Barry is a professional archaeologist, heritage consultant and cultural heritage advisor with over 15 
year’s industry experience in Australia and Europe. His experience covers heritage and archaeological 
compliance on large and small scale rural and urban projects for the private and public sector. Barry 
holds a BA Hons and MA in history and archaeology from Trinity College Dublin. 

1.4 

Location 

The  subject  site  is  the  Victorian  Heritage  Inventory  (VRI)  site  H7822-2338  University  of  Melbourne 
Veterinary Research Institute at 30-36 Flemington Road, Parkville 3052. The subject site is hexagonal 
in shape and is bounded by Story Street to the north, Park Drive to the west, Flemington Road to the 
south west, the Royal Melbourne hospital to the south east and University High School to the east.

1 2.  HISTORICAL BACKGROUND' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5179_Archaeological Investigations at the Veterinary Research Institute The Uni of Melb .pdf'}

page_content='Trench 2 was located at the south eastern extent of the development footprint and was excavated as 
a result of the Aboriginal Cultural Heritage uncovered in Trench 1 and the subsequent CHMP 13770. 

The following report presents the results of the historical excavation.  

Recommendations 

Archaeological  works  conducted  under  Consent  C986  have  determined  the  location,  nature  and 
extent of the historical archaeological material present in the area of investigation.  

The Veterinary Research Institute (VRI) site remains a registered historical archaeological site on the 
Victorian  Heritage  Inventory  (VHI).  Future  management  recommendations  of  the  site  will  be 
determined by Heritage Victoria.  

Heritage Victoria must be informed well in advance of proposed future ground works and they will 
advise on what additional historical archaeological and compliance works, if any, will be required. 

ii' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5179_Archaeological Investigations at the Veterinary Research Institute The Uni of Melb .pdf'}

page_content='21 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
\x0cVeterinary Research Institute H7822-2338 

3.2 

Methodology 

The following Methodology is adapted from Green Heritage’s Excavation Handbook, Green et al 2014 
prepared  as  part of  the  Green  Heritage  Compliance and  Research  standard  practices  for  historical 
excavations and the supporting documentation to the Heritage Victoria consent application.  

• 

Location of trenches within the site, and reason for selection 

The excavation will focus on the area to the rear of the Veterinary Research Institute (VRI). A trench 
that will cover both the internal and external space of the former wing of the VRI will be opened to 
determine  if  any of  the  footings  of the  original  building  remain.  The  focus of  investigations  in  the 
external space will be the identification of 19th century deposits from the market or the manure depot.  

•  Trench size and dimensions' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5179_Archaeological Investigations at the Veterinary Research Institute The Uni of Melb .pdf'}

1.paragraph:
Example: The VRI site is located at the southern edge of the development footprint of the 
University of Melbourne campus in Parkville, Victoria, bordered by Story Street to the north, 
Park Drive to the west, Flemington Road to the southwest, the Royal Melbourne Hospital to the 
southeast, and University High School to the east.

page_content='Part 2  

Archaeological Investigation  

20 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
\x0cVeterinary Research Institute H7822-2338 

1 3.  AIMS AND METHODOLOGY      

The historical archaeological investigation was carried out in October 2015. The excavation director 
was Barry Green; the supervisor was Brian Shanahan; site assistants were Laura Campbell and Michael 
Lever. 

3.1 

Aims 

The aim of the investigation is to understand the nature, location and extent of archaeological material 
at the VRI site. This is done firstly through the careful excavation of the site itself but then through 
analysis  of  what  has  been  found  and  answering  questions  in  the  Research  Design.  The  Research 
Design’s goal is to formulate ways to interrogate the datasets generated by the excavation to better 
understand  the  phases of activity  at  the  site. The Research Design  has  three  sections, Descriptive, 
Analytical and Interpretive. 

3.1.1 

Descriptive' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5179_Archaeological Investigations at the Veterinary Research Institute The Uni of Melb .pdf'}

page_content='of the site? 

3.1.3 

Interpretive  

•  How do the results of the archaeological investigation correlate with the historical record 

for the site? 

•  How do the results of the archaeological investigation compare with other excavated early 
20th  educational  buildings,  late  19th  century  market  sites  and  mid-19th  century  manure 
depots in Victoria and south east Australia in general? 

•  What does the artefact assemblage tell us of the material culture of the sites occupants 
and users and how does this relate to written accounts of life at the RVIB site corresponding 
to the phases of occupation and use? 

•  How has the archaeological investigation of the site contributed to our broader knowledge 
of early 20th century educational buildings, late 19th century markets and mid-19th century 
manure depots in Victoria? 

21 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
\x0cVeterinary Research Institute H7822-2338 

3.2 

Methodology' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5179_Archaeological Investigations at the Veterinary Research Institute The Uni of Melb .pdf'}

page_content='for the site? 

The simple nature of the archaeological record corresponds as expected with the historical record.  

•  How  do  the  results  of  the  archaeological  investigation  compare  with  other  excavated 
early  20th  educational  buildings,  late  19th  century  market  sites  and  mid-19th  century 
manure depots in Victoria and south east Australia in general? 

The paucity of the archaeological record prevents the opportunity to address this question.  

•  What does the artefact assemblage tell us of the material culture of the sites occupants 
and users and how does this relate to written accounts of life at the site corresponding to 
the phases of occupation and use? 

Due to the lack artefacts from secure archaeological deposits, the artefact assemblage has no capacity 
to add knowledge of the site and its occupants.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5179_Archaeological Investigations at the Veterinary Research Institute The Uni of Melb .pdf'}

3.paragraph: Example: The excavation site is located at the corner of Swan Street and Franklin Street, within the City of Melbourne local government area.
source:
page_content='1.3 

Project Archaeologist 

The Project Archaeologist for this investigation is Barry Green.  

Barry is a professional archaeologist, heritage consultant and cultural heritage advisor with over 15 
year’s industry experience in Australia and Europe. His experience covers heritage and archaeological 
compliance on large and small scale rural and urban projects for the private and public sector. Barry 
holds a BA Hons and MA in history and archaeology from Trinity College Dublin. 

1.4 

Location 

The  subject  site  is  the  Victorian  Heritage  Inventory  (VRI)  site  H7822-2338  University  of  Melbourne 
Veterinary Research Institute at 30-36 Flemington Road, Parkville 3052. The subject site is hexagonal 
in shape and is bounded by Story Street to the north, Park Drive to the west, Flemington Road to the 
south west, the Royal Melbourne hospital to the south east and University High School to the east.   

Table 1: Cadastral information' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5179_Archaeological Investigations at the Veterinary Research Institute The Uni of Melb .pdf'}

page_content='4.1 

Trench 1 

Trench 1 was located along the northern extent of the development footprint in the location of the 
former experimentation wing of the VRI building. It uncovered the remains of the eastern extent of 
the original VRI building (Structure A), built in 1909-1910 and demolished in the 1980s. There were no 
above ground structural remains or subfloor deposits. The footings exposed in Trench 1  measured 
12.3m by 5m and consisted of 2 – 3 courses of brickwork. The footings were covered by clean fill and 
cut  in  to  sterile  fill  above  natural  clay.  The  sterile  fill  was  likely  laid  during  deodorisation  works 
undertaken  in  the  1860s  on  the  former  City  of  Melbourne  manure  depot.  This  fill  contained  the 
Aboriginal Cultural Heritage discussed in CHMP 13770.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5179_Archaeological Investigations at the Veterinary Research Institute The Uni of Melb .pdf'}

page_content='Significance of Phase 2 Archaeology 

High – few archaeological investigations of Victorian municipal manure depots have been undertaken 
globally  and  none  have  been  undertaken  in  Australia.  Investigation  of  depot  features  will  greatly 
enhance the body of knowledge on Victorian sanitation and waste management practices. 

Phase 3. 1866 – 1910: City depot / market reserve 

This phase is the least well understood period of the site’s history. Residential occupation is extremely 
unlikely and remediation works on the manure depot would have taken many years to complete. The 
site probably functioned as general depot for Melbourne City Council, perhaps for the storage of road 
building and construction material such as stone and timber. It may also have functioned as a cattle 
market but this is unclear. 

Nature of Phase 3 Archaeology' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5179_Archaeological Investigations at the Veterinary Research Institute The Uni of Melb .pdf'}

page_content='Trench 1 was located along the northern extent of the development footprint in the location of the 
former experimentation wing of the VRI building. It uncovered the remains of the eastern extent of 
the original VRI building, built in 1909-1910 and demolished in the 1980s. There were no above ground 
structural remains or subfloor deposits. The footings exposed in Trench 1 measured 12.3m by 5m and 
consisted of 2 – 3 courses of brickwork. The footings were covered by clean fill and cut in to sterile fill 
above natural clay. The sterile fill was likely laid during deodorisation works undertaken in the 1860s 
on the former City of Melbourne manure depot. This fill contained the Aboriginal Cultural Heritage 
discussed in CHMP 13770. 

Trench 2 was located at the south eastern extent of the development footprint and was excavated as 
a result of the Aboriginal Cultural Heritage uncovered in Trench 1 and the subsequent CHMP 13770.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5179_Archaeological Investigations at the Veterinary Research Institute The Uni of Melb .pdf'}
